pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.2: At that time Venerable Upananda the Sakyan had become skilled at making robes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.3: He made an upper robe of old cloth, well-dyed and beautifully executed, and he wore it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.4: Just then a certain wanderer who was wearing an an expensive robe approached Upananda and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.6: Please give it to me in exchange for my robe.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.7: “But do you know what you’re doing?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.10: The wanderer put on the upper robe and went to the wanderers’ monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.11: And the wanderers said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.12: “This upper robe of yours is beautiful.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.15: “But how long will this upper robe last you?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.16: That robe of yours was better.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.17: The wanderer realized they were right,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.18: and so he returned to Upananda and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.19: “Here’s your upper robe; give me back my robe.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.20: “But didn’t I ask you if you knew what you were doing?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.22: Then that wanderer complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.23: “Even householders give back to other householders who have regrets.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.24: How then can an ascetic not give back to another ascetic?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.25: The monks heard the complaints of that wanderer,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.26: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.27: “How can Venerable Upananda barter with a wanderer?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.28: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.29: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.32: “… Foolish man, how can you barter with a wanderer?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.33: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.34: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:1.35.1: ‘If a monk barters in various ways, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.6: robes, almsfood, a dwelling, or medicines; even a bit of bath powder, a toothbrush, or a piece of string.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.8: if he misbehaves, saying, “Give that for this,” “Bring that for this,” “Swap that with this,” “Exchange that for this,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.9: When it has been bartered—his own goods are in the hands of the other and the other’s goods are in his own hands—it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.10: The goods should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.11: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.12: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.13: ‘Venerables, I have bartered in various ways.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.15: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.19.1: If it is bartering, and he perceives it as such, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.20: If it is bartering, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.21: If it is bartering, but he does not perceive it as such, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.22: If it is not bartering, but he perceives it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.23: If it is not bartering, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.24: If it is not bartering, and he does not perceive it as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.26: if he asks for the price;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.28: if he says, “I have this and I have need of such-and-such;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.30: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np20:2.31: The tenth rule, the training rule on bartering, is finished.
